org.usfirst.frc.team6934.robot.subsystems

Class S_arm

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.SendableBase
      • edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.command.Subsystem
        • org.usfirst.frc.team6934.robot.subsystems.S_arm
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Sendable

    public class S_arm
extends edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.command.Subsystem

    S_Arm

    This class is a subsystem for the arm. The arm, as I refer to it in code, is strictly the long alumunium bars that are lifted up and down by the motors on the back. While moving the arms does also move the gripper and spinners, they are not affected by the arm subsystem and thus, are not classified as part of the arm. Every action that the arm needs to do is coded into this subsystem. Any action you need to do using the arm would use this subsystem to lay out the steps for the action. The arm subsystem contains objects for the motor controllers that move the arm, a limit switch, and a counter for the limit switch. Ideally, this kind of subsytem should utilize encoders.
    Since:
    sometime in the 2018 season...
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Joey F. - Team 6934

      Deprecated. 
      This was programmed when we did not have encoders. As a result, this is just an estimate of what would hold up the arm. It almost works, but it's main flaw is that the power to the motors changes with battery percentage so at full charge it might be too strong and at low charge too weak.

    • Method Detail

      • isSwitchSet

        public boolean isSwitchSet()
        Checks if the limit switch has been hit. A counter is used instead a boolean in case the arm moves too fast and passes over the limit switch.
        Returns:
        boolean value of if the limit switch has been hit

      • initializeCounter

        public void initializeCounter()
        Resets the limit switch counter back to 0.

      • armMove

        public void armMove(double joyAxis)
        Resets the limit switch counter back to 0.
        Parameters:
        joyAxis - input value from the arm controller

      • armStop

        public void armStop()
        Stops the arm motors.

      • holdArm

        public void holdArm()
        Deprecated. This was programmed when we did not have encoders. As a result, this is just an estimate of what would hold up the arm. It almost works, but it's main flaw is that the power to the motors changes with battery percentage so at full charge it might be too strong and at low charge too weak.
        Attempts to hold the arm in place.

      • liftArm

        public void liftArm()
        Deprecated. This was mostly a guesstimate of an action. The physical kickstands didn't cooperate super well and due to our limited autonomous program it was rarely used.
        Briefly lifts the robot's arm to remove kickstands.

      • raiseToSwitch

        public void raiseToSwitch()
        Deprecated. Due to lack of encoders, once again this is merely an estimate. This also had no function in autonomous since the kickstands allowed the power cube to be properly placed anyway.
        Raises the arm to appropriate height to place a power cube in a switch.

      • raiseToScale

        public void raiseToScale()
        Deprecated. Due to lack of encoders, once again this is merely an estimate. The robot was unable to reach the scale and thus is useless.s
        Raises the arm to appropriate height to shoot a power cube into the scale.

      • lowerArm

        public void lowerArm()
        Deprecated. Due to minmal autonomous program functionality, the arm never needed to lower to grab a second cube. The motor speeds were once again estimates and were not very helpful.
        Gently lowers the arm to resting position.

      • getLimSwitch

        public boolean getLimSwitch()
        Standard getter method.
        Returns:
        limitSwitch object to read further from.

      • adjustSpeed

        public double adjustSpeed(double input)
        A manual scaling method that attempts to round the input values in order to make the input less finicky and allow the operator to hold a steady value easily.
        Parameters:
        input - the value that is to be adjusted
        Returns:
        the adjusted input value
